text:
<@U0128E7BEHW>, <@UUE6E1LA1>, <@UEA14GBRR>, you guys seems to know C#...do you mind if I ask a question please?
One of the applications Im running is an old version...its been chugging away for years so reluctant to change really...
However I got this feed back from ChatGpt :
Usage of HttpWebRequest: The code snippet shows the use of `HttpWebRequest`. While this is still a valid class in .NET, it's considered somewhat outdated compared to newer HTTP client libraries like `HttpClient`. If not already updated later in the code, consider using `HttpClient` for more efficient network operations and better support for asynchronous operations.
-----
in your view, would you think this a priority to change to HttpClient ?
(It may well be that the outdated version is successful because it is slower perhaps, so if I did update, maybe Id run AB tests  old v new etc)
Anyway, Id welcome your thoughts please? (Im wondering if its a no brainer to update to asynchronous?) Thanks

text: As always, this depends how your program works. As chatGpt says, if you use async operations, you should move to the more modern httpClient. Also, i believe httpClient is better at reusing your connections, so it would probably be somewhat faster

elements.text: As always, this depends how your program works. As chatGpt says, if you use async operations, you should move to the more modern httpClient. Also, i believe httpClient is better at reusing your connections, so it would probably be somewhat faster

text: The streaming stuff would be through a socket, so http client (like python requests) would only be used for polling stuff like login, get balance, etc?

elements.text: The streaming stuff would be through a socket, so http client (like python requests) would only be used for polling stuff like login, get balance, etc?

text: I don't "know" C# really <@UQL0QDEKA> - I just work with compiled languages rather than interpreted languages (hence the earlier question). While updating can be a good thing, if you've been running an app profitably for YEARS, why risk changing it? Maybe base a new app off the old code, update all internals then run it with a different strat (with roughly same bet placement density) and compare bet placement latencies and see if there is a significant difference? Then if you notice a change (for the better) consider upgrading the old app?  Using 3rd party closed source components is always tricky - quality of documentation can vary! I was burned heavily in 2022 using a 3rd party async HTTPS component that I had failed to read the small print for.
